JMHO, but if President Obama is approximately 50% sucessful in coming through with his election promises, and the economy starts making a recovery in late 2010; and with troops finally coming home from Iraq, I expect him to be reelected in 2012. No one in their right mind, expects the POTUS to be 100% on track with campaign promises made last year, except maybe some extreme lefties, of which I am not. Arlen Specter defected in the Senate. Al Franken will eventually win his Senate seat despite the Coleman law suits. People like Jack Murtha, Nancy Pelosi, and John Kerry who the Right loves to hate, always end up being reelected. Despite being hated by most rural and red state areas of the country, these folks are very popular in their own states of origin. I don't see that changing at all. A matter of fact, I see the Congress not only staying Democrat in 2010, but also gaining more House and Senate seats. You and I will always be on a different page. When I listened to the President's press conference yesterday from the East Wing, I heard him answer questions from reporters and did so in his hallmark intelligent and eloquent way. He just gets better and better! I like Robert Gibbs, and even though it is "sometimes" the duty of the Press Secretary to give a spin, for the most part he answers 'very tough qustions' in a positive, articulate, and informative way. That must be the toughest job of all to be WH-PRSEC. During Bush, Tony Snow often got caught up in that same spin cycle. That said, I'll take Gibbs anyday over Snow! And, if supporting a national health care system, while supporting Social Security in govt. rather than private sector, makes me a Socialist, then I have no problem with that. For those who take it one step further and call me a Soviet Marxist Leninist; that's when I have a problem with labels! No one can accurately predict what the future holds for our political system. 2010 is upon us, and 2012 is still a good ways down the road. So we're all making predictions and assmuptions based on what we already know. Many things unpredictable can and will happen in the meantime. You can bank on it! Perhaps even a "3rd" US political party might evolve to challenge the other two? And if it does, God knows what page we'll be on? You and I might still be able to find "some" common ground...... No one starts a war--or rather, no one in his senses ought to do so--without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. Carl von Clausewitz

reply: JMHO, but if President Obama is approximately 50% sucessful in coming through with his election promises, and the economy starts making a recovery in late 2010; and with troops finally coming home from Iraq, I expect him to be reelected in 2012. No one in their right mind, expects the POTUS to be 100% on track with campaign promises made last year, except maybe some extreme lefties, of which I am not. Arlen Specter defected in the Senate. Al Franken will eventually win his Senate seat despite the Coleman law suits. People like Jack Murtha, Nancy Pelosi, and John Kerry who the Right loves to hate, always end up being reelected. Despite being hated by most rural and red state areas of the country, these folks are very popular in their own states of origin. I don't see that changing at all. A matter of fact, I see the Congress not only staying Democrat in 2010, but also gaining more House and Senate seats. You and I will always be on a different page. When I listened to the President's press conference yesterday from the East Wing, I heard him answer questions from reporters and did so in his hallmark intelligent and eloquent way. He just gets better and better! I like Robert Gibbs, and even though it is "sometimes" the duty of the Press Secretary to give a spin, for the most part he answers 'very tough qustions' in a positive, articulate, and informative way. That must be the toughest job of all to be WH-PRSEC. During Bush, Tony Snow often got caught up in that same spin cycle. That said, I'll take Gibbs anyday over Snow! And, if supporting a national health care system, while supporting Social Security in govt. rather than private sector, makes me a Socialist, then I have no problem with that. For those who take it one step further and call me a Soviet Marxist Leninist; that's when I have a problem with labels! No one can accurately predict what the future holds for our political system. 2010 is upon us, and 2012 is still a good ways down the road. So we're all making predictions and assmuptions based on what we already know. Many things unpredictable can and will happen in the meantime. You can bank on it! Perhaps even a "3rd" US political party might evolve to challenge the other two? And if it does, God knows what page we'll be on? You and I might still be able to find "some" common ground...... No one starts a war--or rather, no one in his senses ought to do so--without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. Carl von Clausewitz

Yes, your liberal turned socialist party has won but, will lose it quickly. I can't wait to "rub you spewage" back in your face. Just saying... JMHO, but if President Obama is approximately 50% sucessful in coming through with his election promises, and the economy starts making a recovery in late 2010; and with troops finally coming home from Iraq, I expect him to be reelected in 2012. No one in their right mind, expects the POTUS to be 100% on track with campaign promises made last year, except maybe some extreme lefties, of which I am not. Arlen Specter defected in the Senate. Al Franken will eventually win his Senate seat despite the Coleman law suits. People like Jack Murtha, Nancy Pelosi, and John Kerry who the Right loves to hate, always end up being reelected. Despite being hated by most rural and red state areas of the country, these folks are very popular in their own states of origin. I don't see that changing at all. A matter of fact, I see the Congress not only staying Democrat in 2010, but also gaining more House and Senate seats. You and I will always be on a different page. When I listened to the President's press conference yesterday from the East Wing, I heard him answer questions from reporters and did so in his hallmark intelligent and eloquent way. He just gets better and better! I like Robert Gibbs, and even though it is "sometimes" the duty of the Press Secretary to give a spin, for the most part he answers 'very tough qustions' in a positive, articulate, and informative way. That must be the toughest job of all to be WH-PRSEC. During Bush, Tony Snow often got caught up in that same spin cycle. That said, I'll take Gibbs anyday over Snow! And, if supporting a national health care system, while supporting Social Security in govt. rather than private sector, makes me a Socialist, then I have no problem with that. For those who take it one step further and call me a Soviet Marxist Leninist; that's when I have a problem with labels! No one can accurately predict what the future holds for our political system. 2010 is upon us, and 2012 is still a good ways down the road. So we're all making predictions and assmuptions based on what we already know. Many things unpredictable can and will happen in the meantime. You can bank on it! Perhaps even a "3rd" US political party might evolve to challenge the other two? And if it does, God knows what page we'll be on? You and I might still be able to find "some" common ground...... No one starts a war--or rather, no one in his senses ought to do so--without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. Carl von Clausewitz

We the people are getting bored with Obama's mini speeches instead of answering the F-ing question; Joe Bidens' "sharp as a bowling ball" statements; Robert Gibbs' spin and tap dancing. Yes, your liberal turned socialist party has won but, will lose it quickly. I can't wait to "rub you spewage" back in your face. Just saying... JMHO, I could be wrong...

title: Something Good about President Obama

content: quote: Originally posted by MilitaryFanSupporter: quote: Originally posted by ProgMod: My response is simply Bring it On! Pssst, Prog, They already have. While you and the rest of the libs are laughing at the antics of the "tea party" citizens, they will bite you from behind. Keep slurping the kool aid because you will wonder what happened when the "old and passe" republicans take back the House and Senate. The silent majority has had enough, and it's boiling over and you and the rest of the libs will be knashing your teeth. We the people are getting bored with Obama's mini speeches instead of answering the F-ing question; Joe Bidens' "sharp as a bowling ball" statements; Robert Gibbs' spin and tap dancing. Yes, your liberal turned socialist party has won but, will lose it quickly. I can't wait to "rub you spewage" back in your face. Just saying... JMHO, but if President Obama is approximately 50% sucessful in coming through with his election promises, and the economy starts making a recovery in late 2010; and with troops finally coming home from Iraq, I expect him to be reelected in 2012. No one in their right mind, expects the POTUS to be 100% on track with campaign promises made last year, except maybe some extreme lefties, of which I am not. Arlen Specter defected in the Senate. Al Franken will eventually win his Senate seat despite the Coleman law suits. People like Jack Murtha, Nancy Pelosi, and John Kerry who the Right loves to hate, always end up being reelected. Despite being hated by most rural and red state areas of the country, these folks are very popular in their own states of origin. I don't see that changing at all. A matter of fact, I see the Congress not only staying Democrat in 2010, but also gaining more House and Senate seats. You and I will always be on a different page. When I listened to the President's press conference yesterday from the East Wing, I heard him answer questions from reporters and did so in his hallmark intelligent and eloquent way. He just gets better and better! I like Robert Gibbs, and even though it is "sometimes" the duty of the Press Secretary to give a spin, for the most part he answers 'very tough qustions' in a positive, articulate, and informative way. That must be the toughest job of all to be WH-PRSEC. During Bush, Tony Snow often got caught up in that same spin cycle. That said, I'll take Gibbs anyday over Snow! And, if supporting a national health care system, while supporting Social Security in govt. rather than private sector, makes me a Socialist, then I have no problem with that. For those who take it one step further and call me a Soviet Marxist Leninist; that's when I have a problem with labels! No one can accurately predict what the future holds for our political system. 2010 is upon us, and 2012 is still a good ways down the road. So we're all making predictions and assmuptions based on what we already know. Many things unpredictable can and will happen in the meantime. You can bank on it! Perhaps even a "3rd" US political party might evolve to challenge the other two? And if it does, God knows what page we'll be on? You and I might still be able to find "some" common ground...... No one starts a war--or rather, no one in his senses ought to do so--without first being clear in his mind what he intends to achieve by that war and how he intends to conduct it. Carl von Clausewitz
